name: Haunter

attacks.name: Hypnosis
attacks.text: The Defending Pokémon is now Asleep.

attacks.name: Dream Eater
attacks.text: You can't use this attack unless the Defending Pokémon is Asleep.

flavorText: Because of its ability to slip through block walls, it is said to be from another dimension.

strengths: Hypnosis guarantees Sleep with no coin flip required
Dream Eater deals 50 damage for only 2 Psychic energy - excellent efficiency
Sleep prevents opponent from attacking or retreating
No weakness makes Haunter resistant to type-based counters
Fighting resistance helps against Hitmonchan and Machamp
Low retreat cost enables easy switching if needed
Can lock down opponents who lack benched Pokémon
Combo can be set up quickly with just 2 energy
weaknesses: Dream Eater is useless if opponent wakes up from Sleep
Opponent can switch to bench to break the lock
60 HP is low for a Stage 1 Pokémon
Sleep status only has 50% chance to persist each turn
Switch and Full Heal completely counter the strategy
Requires evolving from Gastly, adding setup time
If opponent wakes up, you must use Hypnosis again, losing damage output
synergies: Gengar - Evolution option if Haunter strategy fails
Mr. Mime - Protects Haunter with Invisible Wall
Switch - Allows you to reset if opponent is about to wake up
Gust of Wind - Brings up opponent's Pokémon without Switch cards
Pokémon Center - Heals Haunter while maintaining Sleep lock
Energy Search - Finds Psychic energy to maintain attacks
counters: Switch - Allows opponent to escape Sleep lock completely
Full Heal - Removes Sleep status instantly
Gust of Wind - Opponent can bring up benched Pokémon to break lock
Strong basic attackers - Can knock out Haunter before it sets up
Mr. Mime - Invisible Wall blocks Dream Eater's 50 damage
Alakazam - Can move damage around even while Asleep

description: Haunter is a Stage 1 Psychic-type Pokémon that employs a powerful sleep-lock strategy through its Hypnosis and Dream Eater combo. With 60 HP and no weakness, Haunter can establish control over opponents by forcing Sleep status and then dealing massive 50 damage while they're incapacitated. This combination makes Haunter one of the most effective status-based control Pokémon in the Base Set, though its strategy relies on the opponent remaining Asleep.
competitiveHistory: Haunter saw moderate competitive play in the Base Set era, primarily as a component of Gengar evolution decks but occasionally as a standalone strategy. The Hypnosis-Dream Eater combo was powerful and could completely shut down unprepared opponents, making Haunter a legitimate threat. However, experienced players adapted by including Switch and maintaining developed benches, which reduced Haunter's effectiveness. The card was particularly strong in best-of-one formats where opponents might not be prepared, but struggled in longer tournament matches where players could sideboard or adapt.

rulings.ruling: No. You can only use Dream Eater if the Defending Pokémon is Asleep at the moment you declare and use the attack.
Between turns, after all end-of-turn effects. The Asleep Pokémon's controller flips a coin - heads means it wakes up.
No. While Asleep, a Pokémon cannot attack or retreat. The player must use a Trainer card like Switch or wait to wake up.
The Pokémon remains Asleep. You cannot apply Sleep status twice or extend the duration.
No. Benching a Pokémon removes all status conditions, including Sleep.
